description: '''{{Lang|de|Neue Deutsche Härte|italic=no}}''' ({{IPA|de|ˈnɔʏə ˈdɔʏtʃə ˈhɛʁtə|lang}}; {{lit}} "New German Hardness", sometimes abbreviated as '''NDH'''), also known as '''dance-metal''',{{efn|Term used to describe NDH bands that don't sing in German}} is a [[crossover (music)|crossover]] style drawing from [[Neue Deutsche Welle]], [[alternative metal]], [[groove metal]], [[electro-industrial]] and [[techno]]. It developed in Germany and Austria during the early-to-mid 1990s and early 2000s. Alluding to the style of Neue Deutsche Welle, the term was coined by the music press after the 1995 release of [[Rammstein]]'s first studio album ''[[Herzeleid]]''.
